mainmatter.p: In the following we work in NBG set theory with the axiom of choice but not of global choice. I will probably crack at some point and bring in universes. I intend for these notes to be as self contained as possible, but that goal may change.

A category \mathsf{C} consists of classes C_0, C_1, class functions s,t : C_1 \to C_0, a common section \operatorname{id} : C_0 \to C_1 of s, t, and a partial operator \circ : C_1 \times C_1 \rightharpoonup C_1 where f \mathbin{\circ} g is defined iff s(f) = t(g). The axioms of a category are:

ol.li: s( f \mathbin{\circ} g ) = s(g) and t( f \mathbin{\circ} g ) = t(f) for any f, g \in C_1 such that s(f) = t(g),
\operatorname{id} _{ t(f) } \mathbin{\circ} f = f = f \mathbin{\circ} \operatorname{id} _{ s(f) } for any f \in C_1,
for any f, g, h \in C_1 such that s(f) = t(g) and s(g) = t(h), f \mathbin{\circ} ( g \mathbin{\circ} h ) = ( f \mathbin{\circ} g ) \mathbin{\circ} h .

mainmatter.p: As above, we usually write \circ as an infix operator and write application of \operatorname{id} with a subscript.

If x,y \in C_0 we define \operatorname{Hom} _{ \mathsf{C} }( x , y ) = s ^{ -1 } (x) \cap t ^{ -1 } (y), so \operatorname{id} _{ x } \in \operatorname{Hom} _{ \mathsf{C} }( x , x ). For f \in C_1 we refer to s(f) as the "source" of f and t(f) as the "target" of f. A category \mathsf{C} is said to be small if C_1 is a set (which implies C_0 is a set) and to be locally small if \operatorname{Hom} _{ \mathsf{C} }( x , y ) is a set for all x, y \in C_0. For a general category \mathsf{C} we refer to \operatorname{Hom} _{ \mathsf{C} }( x , y ) as a \operatorname{Hom}-class of \mathsf{C}, and if \mathsf{C} is locally small we call it a \operatorname{Hom}-set. We write \operatorname{Obj} ( \mathsf{C} ) for the class C_0 and \operatorname{Mor} ( \mathsf{C} ) for C_1.

Let \mathsf{C} and \mathsf{D} be categories. A functor F : \mathsf{C} \to \mathsf{D} consists of class functions F_0 : \operatorname{Obj} ( \mathsf{C} ) \to \operatorname{Obj} ( \mathsf{D} ) and F_1 : \operatorname{Mor} ( \mathsf{C} ) \to \operatorname{Mor} ( \mathsf{D} ). The axioms of a functor are:

ol.li: F_1( \operatorname{id} _{ x } ) = \operatorname{id} _{ F_0(x) } for any x \in \mathsf{C} _0,
s(F_1(f)) = F_0(s(f)) and t(F_1(f)) = F_0(t(f)) for any f \in \mathsf{C} _1,
for any f, g \in C_1 if s(f) = t(g) then F_1( f \mathbin{\circ} g ) = F_1(f) \mathbin{\circ} F_1(g).

mainmatter.p: If \mathsf{C} is small then the functions F_0 : \operatorname{Obj} ( \mathsf{C} ) \to \operatorname{Obj} ( \mathsf{D} ), F_1 : \operatorname{Mor} ( \mathsf{C} ) \to \operatorname{Mor} ( \mathsf{D} ) are actually sets (not proper classes), as their domains are sets. There is then a class of all functors \mathsf{C} \to \mathsf{D} (even if \mathsf{D} is large). For x \in \operatorname{Obj} ( \mathsf{C} ) and f \in \operatorname{Mor} ( \mathsf{C} ) we'll generally write F(x) to mean F_0(x) and F(f) to mean F_1(f); this is undoubtedly ambiguous, but it's usually clear which is meant from context.

Let \mathsf{C}, \mathsf{D} be categories and F, G : \mathsf{C} \to \mathsf{D} functors between them. The data of a natural transformation \alpha : F \to G is a class function \operatorname{Obj} ( \mathsf{C} ) \to \operatorname{Mor} ( \mathsf{D} ) (also denoted \alpha). The axioms of a natural transformation are:

ol.li: For any f \in \operatorname{Mor} ( \mathsf{C} ), if x = s(f) and y = t(f) then \alpha _y \mathbin{\circ} F(f) = G(f) \mathbin{\circ} \alpha _x.

mainmatter.p: As above, we usually write application of natural transformations with a subscript.

In analogy with representation theory we could think of \alpha as an "intertwiner" betwen F and G. As functors are morphisms between categories, natural transformations are morphisms between categories. Also, if \mathsf{C} is a small category and F, G are functors out of \mathsf{C} \to \mathsf{D} then individual natural transformations F \to G are sets, hence they can be collected into a class of all natural transformations F \to G.
I'm writing some ongoing notes on category theory right now.
